turns.content:
Ok, let's start with item #1 - Target Market. I think my criteria would be a market that is -

\* quickly accessible so we can learn and earn more quickly
\* is viable to work with as a new / small company (possibly just myself)
\* can easily & affordably access
\* is as profitable as possible (have high-value needs that are well suited to potential AI/ML tooling)
\* is low-risk (e.g. non-regulated, non-critical operations) such that we can learn into our work and reduce risk / effort for likely solutions we offer

First question for this - are there any other criteria I should consider for selecting a target market

Those are great criteria to consider when selecting a target market for your AI/ML consulting business. In addition to those criteria, there are a few other factors you may want to consider:

1. Level of competition: How crowded is the market? Are there already established players in the space? If so, how can you differentiate your services and stand out from the competition?
2. Market size and growth potential: What is the size of the market and how fast is it growing? Is there room for new entrants to capture market share?
3. Customer pain points: What are the specific pain points that your target market is experiencing, and how can your services help address those pain points? This will help ensure that you are offering services that are truly valuable to your target market.
4. Customer demographics: What are the characteristics of your target market? What are their job titles, responsibilities, and pain points? Understanding your target market's demographics can help you tailor your services and marketing to meet their needs.
5. Cost of customer acquisition: How much does it cost to acquire a new customer in your target market? Understanding the cost of customer acquisition can help you determine whether your services will be profitable in the long run.

Considering these additional factors can help you identify a target market that is not only accessible and profitable but also has the potential for long-term growth and success.
Those sound good and make sense. What might 10 additional ideas be for unconventional pricing options we haven't considered yet?

Sure, here are 10 more unconventional pricing options you could consider:

1. Performance-based pricing: This pricing model involves charging a fee based on the performance of the AI/ML tools you develop for the business, such as accuracy, speed, or efficiency.
2. Equity-based pricing: This pricing model involves taking equity in the business you work with instead of cash payments. This could be a good option for startups that may not have a lot of cash on hand.
3. Partnership-based pricing: This pricing model involves forming a partnership with the business you work with and sharing the revenue generated by the AI/ML tools you develop.
4. Referral-based pricing: This pricing model involves offering a discount or commission to businesses that refer new customers to your AI/ML consulting business.
5. Auction-based pricing: This pricing model involves auctioning off your services to the highest bidder. This could be a good option for businesses that are in a hurry to get their AI/ML tools developed and implemented.
6. Reverse-auction-based pricing: This pricing model involves businesses bidding for your services, with the lowest bidder winning the contract. This could be a good option for businesses that are price-sensitive and willing to shop around for the best deal.
7. Risk-sharing pricing: This pricing model involves sharing the risk of developing and implementing AI/ML tools with the business you work with, and adjusting your fees based on the success of the project.
8. Usage-based pricing: This pricing model involves charging a fee based on the amount of usage of the AI/ML tools you develop. This could be a good option for businesses that have variable usage of the tools over time.
9. Bundle-based pricing: This pricing model involves bundling multiple services together and offering them at a discounted price. This could be a good option for businesses that need multiple AI/ML services.
10. Charity-based pricing: This pricing model involves donating a portion of your fees to a charity or non-profit organization. This could be a good way to differentiate your business and attract socially conscious customers.

These are just a few more unconventional pricing options you could consider for your AI/ML consulting business. Depending on your target market and the specific services you offer, you may want to use one or more of these options or develop a customized pricing model. The key is to communicate the value of your services clearly to potential customers and offer pricing options that align with their needs and budget.

Ok, let's look at a marketing plan for this new business. Initially it will just be myself. I could reach out to local business (directly, through events, or other methods) or businesses outside my geography remotely.

What are 20 ideas for how I could start talking to my target market to gauge interest in the services of this new business?

Sure, here are 20 ideas for how you could start talking to your target market and gauging interest in your AI/ML consulting services:

1. Attend industry conferences and events: Attend conferences and events that are relevant to your target market, and network with attendees to generate leads and make connections.
2. Publish blog posts and articles: Write blog posts and articles that demonstrate your expertise in AI/ML, and share them on social media and relevant industry forums.
3. Use social media: Use social media platforms like LinkedIn and Twitter to connect with potential customers and share your expertise in AI/ML.
4. Host webinars: Host webinars to showcase your AI/ML expertise and generate leads.
5. Create a website: Create a website for your consulting business, and use search engine optimization (SEO) techniques to improve your visibility in search results.
6. Offer a free consultation: Offer a free consultation to potential customers to introduce them to your services and generate leads.
7. Use email marketing: Use email marketing to reach out to potential customers and promote your services.
8. Join industry groups: Join industry groups and forums where your target market is active, and participate in discussions to build relationships and generate leads.
9. Attend local business networking events: Attend local business networking events to meet potential customers and generate leads.
10. Partner with complementary businesses: Partner with businesses that offer complementary services to yours and cross-promote each other's services.
11. Use Google AdWords: Use Google AdWords to place ads that target your ideal customer.
12. Offer a referral program: Offer a referral program to incentivize your existing customers to refer new customers to your business.
13. Create case studies: Create case studies that showcase your successes in implementing AI/ML tools for other businesses, and use them to promote your services to potential customers.
14. Use influencer marketing: Identify influencers in your target market, and work with them to promote your services to their followers.
15. Attend trade shows: Attend trade shows that are relevant to your target market, and use them to showcase your services and generate leads.
16. Create a podcast: Create a podcast that covers topics related to AI/ML and share it on social media and relevant industry forums.
17. Use direct mail: Use direct mail campaigns to reach out to potential customers and promote your services.
18. Use video marketing: Create videos that showcase your expertise in AI/ML and share them on social media and relevant industry forums.
19. Offer free trials: Offer a free trial of your AI/ML tools to potential customers to generate interest and build relationships.
20. Use targeted advertising: Use targeted advertising on social media platforms to reach your ideal customer and promote your services.

These are just a few ideas for how you could start talking to your target market and gauging interest in your AI/ML consulting services. Depending on your target market and the specific services you offer, you may want to use one or more of these methods or develop a customized marketing plan. The key is to be creative and persistent in your efforts to reach potential customers and communicate the value of your services.

Ok. In terms of team structure and the execution of work, at the outset it would be just myself. I have solid experience in product management, product design, and web development. I have recent, but significant familiarity with developing machine-learning based tools and automations. I'm open to engaging and building a remote team of other developers, product managers and designers as needed (or ideally folks that have technical and communication skills to cross all three of these disciplines and work directly with clients).

Help me think through how I might stage the build out of my team structure and successfully execute work. For example, what services might make most sense to focus on as an individually initially, how might I want to search and select others who are qualified to help, and how might I adding others to this new business as demand grows. Also, if you have other high-level considerations or suggestions let me know. Feel free to group this feedback in sections.

Sure, here are some high-level considerations and suggestions for staging the build-out of your team structure and executing work for your AI/ML consulting business:

1. Start by focusing on services that leverage your existing skills: Since you will be starting out as a solo consultant, it may be best to focus on AI/ML consulting services that leverage your existing skills in product management, product design, and web development. This will allow you to hit the ground running and build credibility with your initial clients.
2. Determine which services you want to expand into: As you start to build your client base and gain traction, you can start to expand into other AI/ML consulting services. These might include services like AI/ML strategy consulting, AI/ML design and development, and AI/ML project management. Determine which services you want to expand into based on market demand and your team's skills and expertise.
3. Consider building a remote team: Since you will be starting out as a solo consultant, you may want to consider building a remote team of other developers, product managers, and designers to help you execute on larger projects. Look for individuals with technical and communication skills that can cross all three disciplines, and make sure that they are a good fit for your team culture.
4. Hire on an as-needed basis: To keep your overhead low, consider hiring team members on an as-needed basis. This will allow you to scale up or down as demand for your services fluctuates.
5. Use subcontractors: Another option to keep your overhead low is to use subcontractors to help execute on larger projects. This can be a good way to get access to specialized skills and expertise when you need them.
6. Develop clear processes and systems: As you build out your team, it will be important to develop clear processes and systems for project management, communication, and quality assurance. This will help ensure that your team is working efficiently and effectively, and that your clients are receiving high-quality work.
7. Invest in ongoing training and development: To ensure that your team members have the skills and knowledge they need to succeed, invest in ongoing training and development. This can include attending conferences, taking courses, or participating in online learning programs.
8. Maintain a strong focus on client satisfaction: As you build out your team and execute on larger projects, it will be important to maintain a strong focus on client satisfaction. Make sure that you are communicating regularly with your clients, providing high-quality work, and addressing any issues that arise quickly and professionally.

These are just a few high-level considerations and suggestions for staging the build-out of your team structure and executing work for your AI/ML consulting business. As you move forward, make sure to stay flexible and adapt your team structure and services to meet the changing needs of your clients and the market.
